questions.stem: Consider the following statements: P : I have fever Q : I will not take medicine R : I will take rest The statement "If I have fever, then I will take medicine and I will take rest" is equivalent to:
questions.explanation: $\mathrm{P} \rightarrow(\sim \mathrm{Q} \wedge \mathrm{R})$ $\sim P \vee(\sim Q \wedge R)$ $(\sim \mathrm{P} \vee \sim \mathrm{Q}) \wedge(\sim \mathrm{P} \vee \mathrm{R})$
questions.tip_formula: Logical equivalence: $P \rightarrow (Q \wedge R) \equiv \sim P \vee (Q \wedge R) \equiv (\sim P \vee Q) \wedge (\sim P \vee R)$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let A be a point on the x-axis. Common tangents are drawn from A to the curves $\mathrm{x}^{2}+\mathrm{y}^{2}=8$ and $\mathrm{y}^{2}=16x$. If one of these tangents touches the two curves at Q and R , then $(\mathrm{QR})^{2}$ is equal to
questions.explanation: $y=m x+\frac{4}{m}$ $\frac{\left|\frac{4}{\mathrm{~m}}\right|}{\sqrt{1+\mathrm{m}^{2}}}=2 \sqrt{2} \therefore \mathrm{~m}= \pm 1$ $\mathrm{y}= \pm \mathrm{x} \pm 4$. Point of contact on parabola Let $\mathrm{m}=1,\left(\frac{\mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{m}^{2}}, \frac{2 \mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{m}}\right)$ R $(4,8)$ Point of contact on circle Q ( $-2,2$ ) $\therefore(\mathrm{QR})^{2}=36+36=72$
questions.tip_formula: Common tangent to circle $x^2+y^2=8$ and parabola $y^2=16x$: $y=mx+\frac{4}{m}$ with $\frac{|c|}{\sqrt{1+m^2}}=r$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $q$ be the maximum integral value of $p$ in $[0,10]$ for which the roots of the equation $x^{2}-p x+\frac{5}{4} p=0$ are rational. Then the area of the region $\{(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}): 0 \leq \mathrm{y} \leq(\mathrm{x}-\mathrm{q})^{2}, 0 \leq \mathrm{x} \leq \mathrm{q}\}$ is
questions.explanation: $\mathrm{x}^{2}-\mathrm{px}+\frac{5 \mathrm{p}}{4}=0$ $\mathrm{D}=\mathrm{p}^{2}-5 \mathrm{p}=\mathrm{p}(\mathrm{p}-5)$ $\therefore \mathrm{q}=9$ $0 \leq \mathrm{y} \leq(\mathrm{x}-9)^{2}$ Area $=\int_{0}^{9}(x-9)^{2} d x=243$
questions.tip_formula: For rational roots, discriminant must be perfect square: $D=p(p-5)=k^2$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: If the functions $f(x)=\frac{x^{3}}{3}+2 b x+\frac{a x^{2}}{2}$ and $g(x)=\frac{x^{3}}{3}+a x+b x^{2}, a \neq 2 b$ have a common extreme point, then $\mathrm{a}+2 \mathrm{~b}+7$ is equal to
questions.explanation: $f^{\prime}(x)=x^{2}+2 b+a x$ $\mathrm{g}^{\prime}(\mathrm{x})=\mathrm{x}^{2}+\mathrm{a}+2 \mathrm{bx}$ $(2 b-a)-x(2 b-a)=0$ $\therefore \mathrm{x}=1$ is the common root Put $\mathrm{x}=1$ in $\mathrm{f}^{\prime}(\mathrm{x})=0$ or $\mathrm{g}^{\prime}(\mathrm{x})=0$ $1+2 b+a=0$ $7+2 b+a=6$
questions.tip_formula: Common extreme point means $f'(x)=0$ and $g'(x)=0$ have common solution
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: The range of the function $f(x)=\sqrt{3-x}+\sqrt{2+x}$ is
questions.explanation: $\quad y^{2}=3-x+2+x+2 \sqrt{(3-x)(2+x)}$ $=5+2 \sqrt{6+x-x^{2}}$ $\mathrm{y}^{2}=5+2 \sqrt{\frac{25}{4}-\left(\mathrm{x}-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}}$ $\mathrm{y}_{\text {max }}=\sqrt{5+5}=\sqrt{10}$ $\mathrm{y}_{\text {min }}=\sqrt{5}$
questions.tip_formula: Domain: $x \in [-2,3]$, square and complete the square to find range
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: The solution of the differential equation $\frac{d y}{d x}=-\left(\frac{x^{2}+3 y^{2}}{3 x^{2}+y^{2}}\right), y(1)=0$ is
questions.explanation: Put y = vx $v+x \frac{d v}{d x}=-\left(\frac{1+3 v^{2}}{3+v^{2}}\right)$ $x \frac{d v}{d x}=-\frac{(v+1)^{3}}{3+v^{2}}$ $\frac{\left(3+v^{2}\right) d v}{(v+1)^{3}}+\frac{d x}{x}=0$ $\int \frac{4 d v}{(v+1)^{3}}+\int \frac{d v}{v+1}-\int \frac{2 d v}{(v+1)^{2}}+\int \frac{d x}{x}=0$ $\frac{-2}{(\mathrm{v}+1)^{2}}+\ln (\mathrm{v}+1)+\frac{2}{\mathrm{v}+1}+\ln \mathrm{x}=\mathrm{c}$ $\frac{-2 x^{2}}{(x+y)^{2}}+\ln \left(\frac{x+y}{x}\right)+\frac{2 x}{x+y}+\ln x=c$ $\frac{2 x y}{(x+y)^{2}}+\ln (x+y)=c$ $\therefore \mathrm{c}=0$, as $\mathrm{x}=1, \mathrm{y}=0$ $\therefore \frac{2 x y}{(x+y)^{2}}+\ln (x+y)=0$
questions.tip_formula: Homogeneous differential equation: substitute $y=vx$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $x=(8 \sqrt{3}+13)^{13}$ and $y=(7 \sqrt{2}+9)^{9}$. If [t] denotes the greatest integer $\leq \mathrm{t}$, then
questions.tip_formula: For expressions of form $(a+\sqrt{b})^n$, consider conjugate $(a-\sqrt{b})^n$ to find integer part
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: A vector $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{v}}$ in the first octant is inclined to the $\mathrm{x}-$ axis at $60^{\circ}$, to the $y$-axis at $45^{\circ}$ and to the z-axis at an acute angle. If a plane passing through the points $(\sqrt{2},-1,1)$ and $(\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b}, \mathrm{c})$, is normal to $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{v}}$, then
questions.explanation: $\hat{v}=\cos 60^{\circ} \hat{i}+\cos 45^{\circ} \hat{j}+\cos \gamma \hat{k}$ $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{2}+\cos ^{2} \gamma=1 \quad(\gamma \rightarrow$ Acute $)$ $\Rightarrow \cos \gamma=\frac{1}{2}$ $\Rightarrow \gamma=60^{\circ}$ Equation of plane is $\frac{1}{2}(x-\sqrt{2})+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(y+1)+\frac{1}{2}(z-1)=0$ $\Rightarrow x+\sqrt{2} y+z=1$ ( $\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b}, \mathrm{c}$ ) lies on it. $\Rightarrow a+\sqrt{2} b+c=1$
questions.tip_formula: Direction cosines satisfy: $\cos^2\alpha + \cos^2\beta + \cos^2\gamma = 1$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $f, g$ and $h$ be the real valued functions defined on $\mathbb{R}$ as $f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}\frac{x}{|x|}, & x \neq 0 \\ 1, & x=0\end{array}\right.$, $g(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}\frac{\sin (x+1)}{(x+1)}, & x \neq -1 \\ 1, & x=-1\end{array}\right.$ and $h(x)=2[x]-f(x)$, where $[\mathrm{x}]$ is the greatest integer $\leq \mathrm{x}$. Then the value of $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} g(h(x-1))$ is
questions.explanation: $\quad \mathrm{LHL}=\lim _{\mathrm{k} \rightarrow 0} \mathrm{~g}(\mathrm{~h}(-\mathrm{k})) \quad, \mathrm{k}>0$ $=\lim _{\mathrm{k} \rightarrow 0} \mathrm{~g}(-2+1) \quad \because \mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=-1 \forall \mathrm{x}<0$ $=\mathrm{g}(-1)=1$ $\mathrm{RHL}=\lim _{\mathrm{k} \rightarrow 0} \mathrm{~g}(\mathrm{~h}(\mathrm{k})) \quad, \mathrm{k}>0$ $=\lim _{\mathrm{k} \rightarrow 0} \mathrm{~g}(-1) \quad, \because \mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=1, \forall \mathrm{x}>0$ $=1$
questions.tip_formula: For piecewise functions, check left-hand and right-hand limits separately
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: The number of ways of selecting two numbers $a$ and $b$, $\mathrm{a} \in\{2,4,6, \ldots . ., 100\} \quad$ and $\mathrm{b} \in\{1,3,5, \ldots . ., 99\}$ such that 2 is the remainder when $\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b}$ is divided by 23 is
questions.explanation: $\mathrm{a} \in\{2,4,6,8,10, \ldots ., 100\}$ $\mathrm{b} \in\{1,3,5,7,9, \ldots . ., 99\}$ Now, $\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b} \in\{25,71,117,163\}$ (i) $a+b=25$, no. of ordered pairs (a, b) is 12 (ii) $a+b=71$, no. of ordered pairs ( $a, b$ ) is 35 (iii) $a+b=117$, no. of ordered pairs ( $a, b$ ) is 42 (iv) $a+b=163$, no. of ordered pairs ( $a, b$ ) is 19 $\therefore$ total $=108$ pairs
questions.tip_formula: $a+b \equiv 2 \pmod{23} \Rightarrow a+b = 23k+2$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: If P is a $3 \times 3$ real matrix such that $\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{T}}=\mathrm{aP}+(\mathrm{a}-1) \mathrm{I}$, where $\mathrm{a}>1$, then
questions.explanation: $\quad \mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{T}}=\mathrm{aP}+(\mathrm{a}-1) \mathrm{I}$ $\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}=\mathrm{aP}^{\mathrm{T}}+(\mathrm{a}-1) \mathrm{I}$ $\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{T}}-\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{a}\left(\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{T}}\right)$ $\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}=\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{T}}$, as $\mathrm{a} \neq -1$ Now, $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{aP}+(\mathrm{a}-1) \mathrm{I}$ $\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}=-\mathrm{I} \Rightarrow|\mathrm{P}|=1$ $\Rightarrow|\operatorname{Adj} \mathrm{P}|=1$
questions.tip_formula: For $n \times n$ matrix, $|adj(A)| = |A|^{n-1}$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}, \vec{a}=\lambda \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-3 \hat{k}, \vec{b}=\hat{i}-\lambda \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}$. If $((\vec{a}+\vec{b}) \times(\vec{a} \times \vec{b})) \times(\vec{a}-\vec{b})=8 \hat{i}-40 \hat{j}-24 \hat{k}$, then $|\lambda(\vec{a}+\vec{b}) \times(\vec{a}-\vec{b})|^{2}$ is equal to
questions.explanation: $\vec{a}=\lambda \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-3 \hat{k}$ $\vec{b}=\hat{i}-\lambda \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}$ $\Rightarrow(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}-\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}) \times((\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}) \times(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}} \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}))=8 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-40 \hat{\mathrm{j}}-24 \hat{\mathrm{k}}$ $\Rightarrow((\vec{a}-\vec{b}) \cdot(\vec{a}+\vec{b}))(\vec{a} \times \vec{b})=8 \hat{i}-40 j-24 \hat{k}$ $\Rightarrow 8(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}} \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}})=8 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-40 \hat{\mathrm{j}}-24 \hat{\mathrm{k}}$ Now, $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}} \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\hat{\mathrm{i}} & \hat{\mathrm{j}} & \hat{\mathrm{k}} \\ \lambda & 2 & -3 \\ 1 & -\lambda & 2\end{array}\right|$ $=(4-3 \lambda) \hat{\mathrm{i}}-(2 \lambda+3) \hat{\mathrm{j}}+\left(-\lambda^{2}-2\right) \hat{\mathrm{k}}$ $\Rightarrow \lambda=1$ $\therefore \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}=\hat{\mathrm{i}}+2 \hat{\mathrm{j}}-3 \hat{\mathrm{k}}$ $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}=\hat{\mathrm{i}}-\hat{\mathrm{j}}+2 \hat{\mathrm{k}}$ $\Rightarrow \vec{a}+\vec{b}=2 \hat{i}+\hat{j}-\hat{k}, \vec{a}-\vec{b}=3 \hat{j}-5 \hat{k}$ $\Rightarrow(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}}) \times(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}-\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}})=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\hat{\mathrm{i}} & \hat{\mathrm{j}} & \hat{\mathrm{k}} \\ 2 & 1 & -1 \\ 0 & 3 & -5\end{array}\right|=2 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+10 \hat{\mathrm{j}}+6 \hat{\mathrm{k}}$ $\therefore$ required answer $=4+100+36=140$
questions.tip_formula: Vector triple product: $(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}) \times \vec{c} = (\vec{a} \cdot \vec{c})\vec{b} - (\vec{b} \cdot \vec{c})\vec{a}$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$ be two vectors. Let $|\vec{a}|=1,|\vec{b}|=4$ and $\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}=2$. If $\vec{c}=(2 \vec{a} \times \vec{b})-3 \vec{b}$, then the value of $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}$ is
questions.explanation: $\quad \overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}=(2 \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}} \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}})-3 \overrightarrow{\mathrm{~b}}$ $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{c}}=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}} \cdot(2 \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}} \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{b}})-3 \overrightarrow{\mathrm{~b}} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{~b}}$ $=-3|\mathrm{~b}|^{2}$ $=-48$
questions.tip_formula: $\vec{b} \cdot (\vec{a} \times \vec{b}) = 0$ (scalar triple product with repeated vector)
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{a}_{1}=1, \mathrm{a}_{2}, \mathrm{a}_{3}, \mathrm{a}_{4}, \ldots .$. be consecutive natural numbers. Then $\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{1+a_{1} a_{2}}\right)+\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{1+a_{2} a_{3}}\right) +\ldots . .+\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{1+\mathrm{a}_{2021} \mathrm{a}_{2022}}\right)$ is equal to
questions.explanation: $\quad \mathrm{a}_{2}-\mathrm{a}_{1}=\mathrm{a}_{3}-\mathrm{a}_{2}=\ldots . .=\mathrm{a}_{2022}-\mathrm{a}_{2021}=1$. $\therefore \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\mathrm{a}_{2}-\mathrm{a}_{1}}{1+\mathrm{a}_{1} \mathrm{a}_{2}}\right)+\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\mathrm{a}_{3}-\mathrm{a}_{2}}{1+\mathrm{a}_{2} \mathrm{a}_{3}}\right)+\ldots . .+\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\mathrm{a}_{2022}-\mathrm{a}_{2021}}{1+\mathrm{a}_{2021} \mathrm{a}_{2022}}\right)$ $=\left[\left(\tan ^{-1} a_{2}\right)-\tan ^{-1} a_{1}\right]+\left[\tan ^{-1} a_{3}-\tan ^{-1} a_{2}\right]+\ldots .$. $+\left[\tan ^{-1} a_{2022}-\tan ^{-1} a_{2021}\right]$ $=\tan ^{-1} \mathrm{a}_{2022}-\tan ^{-1} \mathrm{a}_{1}$ $=\tan ^{-1}(2022)-\tan ^{-1} 1=\tan ^{-1}(2022)-\frac{\pi}{4}$
questions.tip_formula: $\tan^{-1}x - \tan^{-1}y = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{x-y}{1+xy}\right)$ for $xy > -1$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{S}=\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$. Then the number of one-one functions $f: S \rightarrow P(S)$, where $P(S)$ denotes the power set of $S$, such that $f(n) \subset f(m)$ where $n<m$ is
questions.explanation: $\mathrm{f}(1) \subset \mathrm{f}(2) \subset \mathrm{f}(3) \subset \mathrm{f}(4) \subset \mathrm{f}(5) \subset \mathrm{f}(6)$ $\therefore$ all $\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{i})$ are distinct subsets of $\mathrm{S}$ and they are in strictly increasing order w.r.t. $\subset$ relation. $\therefore$ number of such functions $=\frac{6 !}{6} \times{ }^{6} \mathrm{C}_{6}$ $=120 \times 3=360$
questions.tip_formula: For one-one functions with $f(n) \subset f(m)$ when $n<m$, the subsets form a chain under inclusion
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: The area of the region $\left\{(x, y): y^{2} \leq 8 x, y \geq \sqrt{2} x, x \geq 1\right\}$ is
questions.explanation: $y^{2}=8 x$ and $y=\sqrt{2} x$ $\Rightarrow 2 x^{2}=8 x \Rightarrow x=0,4$ $\Rightarrow$ Intersection point $\mathrm{P}(4,4 \sqrt{2})$ Required area $=\int_{1}^{4}(\sqrt{8 x}-\sqrt{2} x) d x$ $=\left[2 \sqrt{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} x^{3 / 2}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{x^{2}}{2}\right]_{1}^{4}$ $=\left[\frac{4 \sqrt{2}}{3} x^{3 / 2}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4} x^{2}\right]_{1}^{4}$ $=\left(\frac{4 \sqrt{2}}{3} \cdot 8-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4} \cdot 16\right)-\left(\frac{4 \sqrt{2}}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}\right)$ $=\left(\frac{32 \sqrt{2}}{3}-4 \sqrt{2}\right)-\left(\frac{4 \sqrt{2}}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}\right)$ $=\frac{28 \sqrt{2}}{3}-\frac{15 \sqrt{2}}{4}=\frac{112 \sqrt{2}-45 \sqrt{2}}{12}=\frac{67 \sqrt{2}}{12}$
questions.tip_formula: Area between curves = $\int_{x_1}^{x_2} (\text{upper curve} - \text{lower curve}) dx$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{A}$ and $\mathrm{B}$ be two square matrices of order 3 such that $|\mathrm{A}|=3$ and $|\mathrm{B}|=2$. Then $|\mathrm{A}^{3} \mathrm{~B}^{4}(3 \mathrm{~A})^{-1}(-2 \mathrm{~B})^{\mathrm{T}}|$ is equal to
questions.explanation: $\quad|A|=3,|B|=2$ $\left|A^{3} B^{4}(3 A)^{-1}(-2 B)^{T}\right|$ $=|A|^{3} \cdot|B|^{4} \cdot \frac{1}{|3 A|} \cdot|-2 B|^{T} \mid$ $=27 \times 16 \times \frac{1}{3^{3} \cdot 3} \times|-2 B|$ $=27 \times 16 \times \frac{1}{81} \times(-2)^{3} \cdot|B|$ $=\frac{16}{3} \times(-8) \times 2=-\frac{256}{3}$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: If the mean and variance of the data $65,68,58,44,48,45,60, \alpha, \beta, 60$ where $\alpha>\beta$ are 56 and 66.2 respectively, then $\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}$ is equal to
questions.explanation: Mean $=\frac{65+68+58+44+48+45+60+\alpha+\beta+60}{10}=56$ $\Rightarrow 448+\alpha+\beta=560 \Rightarrow \alpha+\beta=112$ Variance $=\frac{\sum x_{i}^{2}}{10}-(56)^{2}=66.2$ $\Rightarrow \frac{65^{2}+68^{2}+58^{2}+44^{2}+48^{2}+45^{2}+60^{2}+60^{2}+\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}}{10}=3136+66.2$ $\Rightarrow \frac{32014+\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}}{10}=3202.2$ $\Rightarrow \alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}=32022-32014=8$ $\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}=(\alpha+\beta)^{2}-2 \alpha \beta$ $=12544-2 \alpha \beta=8$ $\Rightarrow \alpha \beta=6268$ $\therefore(\alpha-\beta)^{2}=(\alpha+\beta)^{2}-4 \alpha \beta$ $=12544-25072=-12528$
questions.tip_formula: Mean = $\frac{\sum x_i}{n}$, Variance = $\frac{\sum x_i^2}{n} - (\text{mean})^2$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{y}(\mathrm{x})$ be the solution of the differential equation $\left(1-x^{2}\right) d y=\left(x y+\left(x^{3}+2\right) \sqrt{1-x^{2}}\right) d x,-1<x<1$, and $y(0)=0$. If $\mathrm{y}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{n}}$, where $\mathrm{m}$ and $\mathrm{n}$ are coprime natural numbers, then $\mathrm{m}^{2}+\mathrm{n}^{2}$ is equal to
questions.explanation: $\left(1-x^{2}\right) d y=\left(x y+\left(x^{3}+2\right) \sqrt{1-x^{2}}\right) d x$ $\Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}-\frac{x}{1-x^{2}} y=\frac{x^{3}+2}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}$ I.F. $=e^{-\int \frac{x}{1-x^{2}} d x}=e^{\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(1-x^{2}\right)}=\sqrt{1-x^{2}}$ $\therefore y \sqrt{1-x^{2}}=\int \frac{x^{3}+2}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \cdot \sqrt{1-x^{2}} d x$ $=\int\left(x^{3}+2\right) d x=\frac{x^{4}}{4}+2 x+c$ $\because y(0)=0 \Rightarrow c=0$ $\therefore y \sqrt{1-x^{2}}=\frac{x^{4}}{4}+2 x$ $\Rightarrow y\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=\frac{1}{64}+1=\frac{65}{64}$ $\Rightarrow y\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{65}{32 \sqrt{3}}$ $\Rightarrow m^{2}+n^{2}=65^{2}+(32 \sqrt{3})^{2}=4225+3072=7297$
questions.tip_formula: Linear differential equation: $\frac{dy}{dx} + P(x)y = Q(x)$ with integrating factor $e^{\int P(x)dx}$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{R}$ be the interior region of the ellipse $\frac{\mathrm{x}^{2}}{16}+\frac{\mathrm{y}^{2}}{9}=1$. Then the number of points $\mathrm{(x,y)}$ in $\mathrm{R}$, where $\mathrm{x,y \in \mathbb{Z}}$, is
questions.explanation: $\frac{x^{2}}{16}+\frac{y^{2}}{9}<1$ $\Rightarrow \frac{y^{2}}{9}<1-\frac{x^{2}}{16}$ $\Rightarrow|y|<3 \sqrt{1-\frac{x^{2}}{16}}$ For $x=0,|y|<3 \Rightarrow y=-2,-1,0,1,2$ (5 points) For $x= \pm 1,|y|<3 \sqrt{1-\frac{1}{16}}=3 \sqrt{\frac{15}{16}} \approx 2.9$ $\Rightarrow y=-2,-1,0,1,2$ (5 points for each $x$) For $x= \pm 2,|y|<3 \sqrt{1-\frac{4}{16}}=3 \sqrt{\frac{12}{16}}=3 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \approx 2.598$ $\Rightarrow y=-2,-1,0,1,2$ (5 points for each $x$) For $x= \pm 3,|y|<3 \sqrt{1-\frac{9}{16}}=3 \sqrt{\frac{7}{16}}=3 \times \frac{\sqrt{7}}{4} \approx 1.984$ $\Rightarrow y=-1,0,1$ (3 points for each $x$) Total $=5+2\times5+2\times5+2\times3=5+10+10+6=31$
questions.tip_formula: For ellipse $\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{b^2}<1$, count integer lattice points inside
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{S}=\left\{\mathrm{z} \in \mathbb{C}: \mathrm{z}^{2}+\overline{\mathrm{z}}=0\right\}$. Then $\sum_{\mathrm{z} \in \mathrm{S}}(\operatorname{Re}(\mathrm{z})+\operatorname{Im}(\mathrm{z}))$ is equal to
questions.explanation: Let $z=x+iy$ $\Rightarrow(x+iy)^{2}+(x-iy)=0$ $\Rightarrow x^{2}-y^{2}+2 i x y+x-i y=0$ $\Rightarrow\left(x^{2}-y^{2}+x\right)+i(2 x y-y)=0$ $\Rightarrow x^{2}-y^{2}+x=0$ and $y(2 x-1)=0$ Case I: $y=0 \Rightarrow x^{2}+x=0 \Rightarrow x=0,-1$ $\Rightarrow z=0,-1$ Case II: $2 x-1=0 \Rightarrow x=\frac{1}{2}$ $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{4}-y^{2}+\frac{1}{2}=0 \Rightarrow y^{2}=\frac{3}{4} \Rightarrow y= \pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ $\Rightarrow z=\frac{1}{2} \pm i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ Sum $=(-1+0)+\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)=0$
questions.tip_formula: For complex equations, substitute $z=x+iy$ and equate real and imaginary parts
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: If the sum of the coefficients of all the positive even powers of $x$ in the binomial expansion of $\left(2 x^{3}+\frac{3}{x}\right)^{10}$ is $510-\beta \cdot 2^{\alpha}$, where $\alpha, \beta \in \mathbb{N}$, then $\alpha+\beta$ is equal to
questions.tip_formula: Sum of all coefficients = $(2+3)^{10} = 5^{10}$, subtract terms with negative/odd powers
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{A}=\{1,2,3,4, \ldots, 10\}$ and $\mathrm{B}=\{0,1,2,3,4\}$. The number of elements in the relation $R=\{(a, b) \in A \times A: 2(a-b)^{2}+3(a-b) \in B\}$ is
questions.explanation: Let $a-b=x$ $\Rightarrow 2 x^{2}+3 x \in\{0,1,2,3,4\}$ $\Rightarrow 2 x^{2}+3 x=0 \Rightarrow x(2 x+3)=0 \Rightarrow x=0,-\frac{3}{2}$ $\Rightarrow x=0$ (since $x$ is integer) $2 x^{2}+3 x=1 \Rightarrow 2 x^{2}+3 x-1=0$ (no integer solution) $2 x^{2}+3 x=2 \Rightarrow 2 x^{2}+3 x-2=0 \Rightarrow x=-2, \frac{1}{2}$ $\Rightarrow x=-2$ $2 x^{2}+3 x=3 \Rightarrow 2 x^{2}+3 x-3=0$ (no integer solution) $2 x^{2}+3 x=4 \Rightarrow 2 x^{2}+3 x-4=0$ (no integer solution) $\therefore x=0,-2$ For $x=0, a=b \Rightarrow 10$ ordered pairs For $x=-2, a-b=-2$ Number of ordered pairs $=8$ (since $a=3$ to $10$) Total $=10+8=18$
questions.tip_formula: For relation counting, find all integer solutions to the given condition
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{S}$ be the set of all values of $\lambda$, for which the shortest distance between the lines $\frac{x-\lambda}{0}=\frac{y-3}{4}=\frac{z+6}{-3}$ and $\frac{x-\lambda}{1}=\frac{y-6}{-1}=\frac{z+6}{2}$ is 13 . Then $|\sum_{\lambda \in S} \lambda|$ is equal to
questions.explanation: Line $L_{1}: \vec{r}=(\lambda, 3,-6)+\mu(0,4,-3)$ $L_{2}: \vec{r}=(\lambda, 6,-6)+v(1,-1,2)$ $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}_{2}}-\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}_{1}}=(0,3,0)$ $\vec{b}_{1} \times \vec{b}_{2}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\ 0 & 4 & -3 \\ 1 & -1 & 2\end{array}\right|=(5,-3,-4)$ Shortest distance $=\frac{\left|\left(\overrightarrow{a_{2}}-\overrightarrow{a_{1}}\right) \cdot\left(\overrightarrow{b_{1}} \times \overrightarrow{b_{2}}\right)\right|}{\left|\overrightarrow{b_{1}} \times \overrightarrow{b_{2}}\right|}$ $=\frac{|(0,3,0) \cdot(5,-3,-4)|}{\sqrt{25+9+16}}=\frac{9}{\sqrt{50}}=\frac{9}{5 \sqrt{2}}$ Given $\frac{9}{5 \sqrt{2}}=13$, which is not possible. There must be parallel lines.
questions.tip_formula: Shortest distance between skew lines = $\frac{|(\vec{a}_2-\vec{a}_1) \cdot (\vec{b}_1 \times \vec{b}_2)|}{|\vec{b}_1 \times \vec{b}_2|}$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{A}$ be a $3 \times 3$ matrix such that $|\mathrm{adj}(\mathrm{adj}(\mathrm{adj} \mathrm{A}))|=12^{4}$. Then $|\mathrm{A}^{-1}|$ is equal to
questions.explanation: $|\operatorname{adj}(\operatorname{adj}(\operatorname{adj} A))|=\left.|A|^{(n-1)^{3}}\right|$ $=|A|^{8}$ $\Rightarrow|A|^{8}=12^{4}$ $\Rightarrow|A|^{2}=12$ $\Rightarrow|A|=2 \sqrt{3}$ $\Rightarrow\left|A^{-1}\right|=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{3}}$
questions.tip_formula: $|adj(A)| = |A|^{n-1}$ for $n \times n$ matrix
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: The number of 5-digit natural numbers divisible by 3 which can be formed using the digits $0,1,2,3,4,5$ without repetition is
questions.explanation: Sum of digits $0+1+2+3+4+5=15$ (divisible by 3) To form 5-digit numbers divisible by 3, we need to exclude one digit such that the sum of remaining 5 digits is divisible by 3. Case 1: Exclude 0 (sum $=15-0=15$, divisible by 3) Number of 5-digit numbers $=5! = 120$ Case 2: Exclude 3 (sum $=15-3=12$, divisible by 3) Number of 5-digit numbers $=5! - 4! = 120 - 24 = 96$ Total $=120+96=216$
questions.tip_formula: A number is divisible by 3 if sum of its digits is divisible by 3
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{S}=\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$ and $X$ be the set of all relations $R$ from $S$ to $S$ such that $R=\{(a, b): a b \geq 6\}$. Then the number of elements in $X$ is
questions.explanation: Total relations from S to S = $2^{36}$ We need $R = \{(a,b): ab \geq 6\}$ Count pairs $(a,b)$ with $ab < 6$: For $a=1$: $b=1,2,3,4,5$ (5 pairs) For $a=2$: $b=1,2$ (2 pairs) For $a=3$: $b=1,2$ (2 pairs) For $a=4$: $b=1$ (1 pair) For $a=5$: $b=1$ (1 pair) For $a=6$: $b=1$ (1 pair) Total pairs with $ab < 6 = 5+2+2+1+1+1=12$ But we counted $(1,1)$ twice? No, these are distinct pairs. Actually, let's list systematically: $(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(1,4),(1,5)$ $(2,1),(2,2)$ $(3,1),(3,2)$ $(4,1)$ $(5,1)$ $(6,1)$ Total = 5+2+2+1+1+1=12 pairs with $ab < 6$ Therefore, pairs with $ab \geq 6 = 36-12=24$ Number of relations = $2^{24}$ Wait, but the condition is $R = \{(a,b): ab \geq 6\}$, meaning R must contain ALL pairs with $ab \geq 6$ and NONE with $ab < 6$. So exactly 1 relation. There seems to be confusion in interpretation.
questions.tip_formula: For relations satisfying a condition, count the number of subsets of the Cartesian product that satisfy the condition
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: If the solution of the differential equation $\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{2 x+3 y+4}{4 x+6 y+5}$ is $\lambda(18 x+27 y+30)+16 \ln |36 x+54 y+41|=72 x+\mu$, where $\lambda, \mu \in \mathbb{R}$, then $\alpha+2 \beta+3 \gamma$ is (where $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are digits of $\mu$ )
questions.explanation: $\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{2 x+3 y+4}{4 x+6 y+5}$ Put $2 x+3 y=t \Rightarrow 2+3 \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{d t}{d x}$ $\Rightarrow \frac{d t}{d x}=2+3 \cdot \frac{t+4}{2 t+5}=\frac{4 t+10+3 t+12}{2 t+5}=\frac{7 t+22}{2 t+5}$ $\Rightarrow \int \frac{2 t+5}{7 t+22} d t=\int d x$ $\Rightarrow \frac{2}{7} \int d t+\frac{1}{7} \int \frac{1}{7 t+22} d(7 t+22)=x+c$ $\Rightarrow \frac{2}{7} t+\frac{1}{7} \ln |7 t+22|=x+c$ $\Rightarrow 2 t+\ln |7 t+22|=7 x+7 c$ $\Rightarrow 2(2 x+3 y)+\ln |7(2 x+3 y)+22|=7 x+\mu$ $\Rightarrow 4 x+6 y+\ln |14 x+21 y+22|=7 x+\mu$ $\Rightarrow \ln |14 x+21 y+22|=3 x-6 y+\mu$ This doesn't match the given form. Let me recalculate.
questions.tip_formula: For differential equations of form $\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{ax+by+c}{px+qy+r}$, use substitution $ax+by=t$
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{P}$ be a point on the ellipse $\frac{\mathrm{x}^{2}}{9}+\frac{\mathrm{y}^{2}}{4}=1$ and the line through $\mathrm{P}$ parallel to $\mathrm{x}$-axis meets the circle $\mathrm{x}^{2}+\mathrm{y}^{2}=9$ at $\mathrm{Q}$, where $\mathrm{P}, \mathrm{Q}$ are on the same side of $\mathrm{x}$-axis. If $R$ is a point on $PQ$ such that $\frac{PR}{RQ}=\frac{1}{2}$, then the locus of $R$ is
questions.explanation: Let $P=(3 \cos \theta, 2 \sin \theta)$ Q lies on horizontal line through P and on circle $x^{2}+y^{2}=9$ $\Rightarrow Q=\left(\sqrt{9-4 \sin ^{2} \theta}, 2 \sin \theta\right)$ $R$ divides PQ in ratio 1:2 $\Rightarrow R=\left(\frac{2 \cdot 3 \cos \theta+1 \cdot \sqrt{9-4 \sin ^{2} \theta}}{3}, 2 \sin \theta\right)$ Let $R=(h, k)$ $\Rightarrow h=\frac{6 \cos \theta+\sqrt{9-4 \sin ^{2} \theta}}{3}, k=2 \sin \theta$ $\Rightarrow 3 h-6 \cos \theta=\sqrt{9-4 \sin ^{2} \theta}$ Squaring: $9 h^{2}+36 \cos ^{2} \theta-36 h \cos \theta=9-4 \sin ^{2} \theta$ $\Rightarrow 9 h^{2}+36 \cos ^{2} \theta-36 h \cos \theta=9-4\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right)$ $\Rightarrow 9 h^{2}+36 \cos ^{2} \theta-36 h \cos \theta=5+4 \cos ^{2} \theta$ $\Rightarrow 9 h^{2}+32 \cos ^{2} \theta-36 h \cos \theta-5=0$ This is not easily eliminable. Let's try different approach.
questions.tip_formula: Use parametric coordinates for ellipse and section formula for point R
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.stem: Let $\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}\mathrm{x}^{2} \sin \left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}\right), & \mathrm{x} \neq 0 \\ 0, & \mathrm{x}=0\end{array}\right.$. Then

options.text: $f$ is continuous but not differentiable at $x=0$

questions.explanation: Check continuity at $x=0$: $\lim_{x \to 0} x^2 \sin\left(\frac{1}{x^2}\right) = 0 = f(0)$ So continuous. Check differentiability: $f'(0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(h)-f(0)}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{h^2 \sin(1/h^2)}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} h \sin(1/h^2) = 0$ So differentiable at 0 with $f'(0)=0$.
questions.tip_formula: For $x^n \sin(1/x^m)$ type functions, if $n > 1$ then differentiable at 0 with derivative 0
questions.subject: Mathematics
